review_title: Best hospital in NY for nurses
job_title: RN Charge Nurse in New York, NY
pros: I have worked at two other hospitals in the city and this one has been the best by far. Generally good patient to nurse ratios, they try their best Excellent benefits Pay is good and they’re always reevaluating. There’s also clinical ladder promotions you can work for that increase your salary decently. Staff is well educated and a lot are back in school because of the excellent NYU tuition reimbursement program Leadership listens and is always trying to improve quality Most nurse leaders I’ve met are very personable and easy to talk to. No egos here! (However the MD and APP side is another story) Lots of opportunities for professional growth within the organization. You can pretty much do anything and can transfer to any units within the organization as long as you have been one year at your current position. Kimmel Pavilion is GORGEOUS to work in and honestly has made a huge impact on my well being. Floor to ceiling windows in the patient rooms and wonderful views of the Empire State Building and East River. Feels luxurious.
cons: They somehow can’t seem to retain experienced nurses at the bedside They hire all new staff (usually new grads) for nightshift and move current staff to dayshift if a position becomes available. This results in a hugely unbalanced skill set on night shift. If you want to work in an ICU that is strictly ICU and high acuity all the time, you only have MICU or SICU as an option. CVICU and CCU are bizarre mixed acuity units that can be very unfulfilling if you want the challenge of ICU. If you’re a telemetry or cardiac step down nurse, you also have to do ICU here which stresses a lot of people out who would be wonderful acute care nurses but don’t want the stress of having ICU patients as well. Travel nurses hate their lives here. The hospital hires them for the float pool and they’re thrown all over the place. Most are ICU nurses but when floated to the “ICUs” they usually get acute patients because the unit gives the ICU patients to their staff. A lot of nurse practitioners can be toxic and don’t know how to educate the bedside nurses without being condescending. Unfortunately it’s the same everywhere and not NYU specific. However, considering most NPs here went to NYU I would hope they add something to their training that focuses on this a bit better.

job_title: Manager (In Corporate) in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Definitely a learning experience, regardless of your background. You will learn a lot, such as learning how to navigate through a large health system. There is stability and the benefits are great.
cons: You will learn a lot about how they do things, but new ideas are often met with resistance. Their leadership approach is heavily top down. Being a large health system leads to a very slow process to implement change, especially with resistance from senior leadership. There is minimum cross-departmental and cross-sector collaboration. Departments operate in silos, leading to inefficiencies. Some leadership is very disrespectful to their teams and other staff . They have an expectation that you work late hours. Stressful environment, and poor resource management. Not open to ideas on how to strategically use available resources, so mismanagement of resources continues. Leaders act more as managers than true leaders.

job_title: Pharmacist in New York, NY
pros: Autonomy, not micromanaged, incredible spectrum of experience, will learn something new every single day. You'll see an incredibly wide range of diseases, and you will work in almost every unit of the hospital, developing a wide range of skills. There are protocols available to you for professional guidance at all times, and you will become a very self sufficient pharmacist with the ability to multitask and think critically and solve almost any problem that comes across your desk.
cons: Horrible work culture. Hard workers are rewarded for doing a good job by being given more work. Your schedule is demanding and inconsistent, you will be working weekends and evenings (4pm-12am) (with one 4-month rotation through overnight, 12am-8am) for the first few years and if you do get on days (8am-4pm), you'll still work every other weekend. Position is union, so everything (schedule, vacation days, holidays, shift preference) is seniority-based with no flexibility. If you can handle an aggressive schedule with little work-life balance, this will be the best job you ever have, hands down. However, if you cannot handle having no work-life balance, you will eventually become miserable.

review_title: Emotion Distress and Guilt Bullying in HR
job_title: Human Resources in New York, NY
pros: At this point it is hard to find many pro's as the department refuses to hear employee concerns.
cons: The Human Resources Department continue to have "vaccine spotlights" to try and convince unvaccinated employees to get the vaccine. At this point, most of the department has gotten the vaccine. These vaccine spotlights are employees sharing deeply personal and emotionally distressing personal stories that are essential trying to guilt and pressure employees that haven't got the vaccine. It would be much more effective for managers of those employees to have one on one conversations versus pressuring and disengaging the rest of the department. The team has shared this with leadership multiple times but they refuse to listen. I have now heard of fellow employees that's parents have died, that they have almost died and it's incredibly inappropriate and overly personal. One employee literally talked about the movie Outbreak and I Am Legend, embarrassing and not how I would expect a healthcasre organization to operate.

review_title: Worthwhile for 2 Types of Employees Only
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: This is a small autonomous psychosocial research group within the much larger NYU Medical School (which, in turn, is a component of NYU Langone Medical Center). The larger institutions only affect this group in terms of policy (e.g., # of vacation days) and benefits (e.g., health insurance), all of which are good (except no maternity leave). Working within the research group per se can be valuable for either young people (such as those just out of college or 1-2 years post-college) who are looking to get some real world experience related to psychology, sociology or public health, or for individuals with advanced degrees (Ph.Ds, M.Ds, etc.) who want to establish themselves in academia, e.g., eventually becoming a Co-Principal Investigator on an NIH grant. In addition, group members are generally supportive of and helpful towards one and other.
cons: If you don't fall into one of the above-named categories (i.e., just starting your career or holding an advanced degree), beware! There's a tacit 2- or 3- tiered system and, if you don't fall into the upper categories, you'll be grossly undervalued, mistreated, and underpaid regardless of your productivity. There's very, very restricted room for growth (again, unless you have a Ph.D., M.D., etc.) so at most one should spend 2-3 years here and then take your experience and move on! Also, the pay is not good compared to many private sector jobs, and all of government-sponsored research has been hard hit by the sequestration, resulting in slashed budgets and a drastic reduction of scientific grant awards. Finally, the boss is a hardcore workaholic and tends to impose unreasonable deadlines.
